paragraphs.text: Oscars delirium: a seasonal condition in which even critics become starstruck.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: With the announcement of the Oscar nominations, we shall undoubtedly see examples of what I call"awards season transference"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: a strange phenomenon that afflicts film journalists called upon to comment on radio and TV
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: I myself am an occasional sufferer
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It's simply the delirium in the air
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Just as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: patients can fall in love with their psychoanalysts
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: so movie journalists can take these prizes very personally
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Critics who are so airily humorous and drily detached the rest of the year will sternly announce that they are actually pretty angry or upset that their personal favourite hasn't been nominated
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They will undergo a radical personality change
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Having steadfastly refused to as much as sip the Kool-Aid for the preceding 12 months
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they suddenly glug down about a gallon of it in five minutes and effectively proclaim their deep personal stake in what happens on Oscar night
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: what is seen as good news produces even more extraordinary behaviour: a kind of luvvyism-by-proxy
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Actual grownup journalists with mortgages and adult responsibilities will coo:"I'm just so delighted for Meryl ..." or"I'm so happy for Emily..."
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Did these starstruck reporters meet the celebs briefly at some press junket or interview?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Did these stars convince these poor unfamous journalists that they were their mates?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I fear so
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And they are therefore brilliant actors, and deserve every Oscar going
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Confectionery lovers are enraged at news that the US owners of Cadbury have been tampering with the recipe for the Cadbury's Creme Egg, and at what they say is an outrageous lack of any consultative process with the consumer
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The shell is no longer made from Cadbury's Dairy Milk but from the inferior "standard cocoa mix"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: This insidious messing with its components could provoke an Indian mutiny among Creme Egg lovers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Surely we need one of those change.org online petitions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I personally have never quite got over my childhood suspicion that the spelling "creme" means that the Creme Egg is not in fact made of actual cream
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But I have been prepared to put these considerations to one side in the cause of continued snacking
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: For me, however, this is not the worst snack-related catastrophe imaginable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Pringles started tinkering with the recipe for their Sour Cream & Onion flavour
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: that would be appalling
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: for example
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: they started using a kind of artificial "creme" instead of "cream", and introduced some form of artificial substitute instead of actual onions
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Unthinkable
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are new and interesting reasons to relish the imminent release of Paul Thomas Anderson's fascinating film Inherent Vice
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: based on Thomas Pynchon's novel of the same name: a quasi-noir about a bleary stoner private detective on the trail of his ex-girlfriend's kidnapped lover
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: It is set in Los Angeles in 1970
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: its black-comic tone of paranoia is crucially set by the horrendous killings carried out in that era by the Charles Manson gang
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Manson passionately wanted those killings to trigger an apocalyptic race war, and was every bit as serious about his ideological vision as the Charlie Hebdo murderers were about theirs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: as an American political issue, racial tension was and is real enough
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But of course no one took Charlie Manson seriously as a revolutionary warrior
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And Thomas Pynchon and Paul Thomas Anderson find the right register to respond
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: with comedy, scorn and a resilient and healthy sense of surreality and the absurd that, however dark, absorbs and transcends hate
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: @PeterBradshaw1
paragraphs.label: no-unit
